signals.headline: Defense tech startup funding doubled to all-time high in 2025: $7.7B across ~100 deals
signals.source: DefenseNews, Jan 20 2026 — https://www.defensenews.com/industry/2026/01/20/defense-tech-startups-had-their-best-funding-year-ever-in-2025/; Crunchbase Sector Snapshot; CB Insights ($17.9B equity funding)
signals.data_point: VC-backed defense startup funding hit $7.7B across ~100 deals in 2025 (Crunchbase), more than 2x the prior year. CB Insights counts $17.9B total equity funding (up from $7.3B in 2024). Anduril raised $2.5B Series G at $30.5B valuation. Saronic $600M Series C. Helsing $694M. Manufacturing-focused defense rose to $4.7B across 39 deals.
signals.relevance: VALIDATES REQ-TN-008-ACCESS: Far exceeds threshold of '3+ startups funded >$10M in 24mo'. Defense AI/national security IS accessible to new entrants with venture backing. Anduril's $30.5B valuation proves fund-returner potential exists. However, accessibility is concentrated in software/AI layers — hardware/platforms remain procurement-locked.
signals.verdict_detail: Software/AI defense layers: VALIDATED (open). Platform/hardware/procurement layers: FALSIFIED (locked). Score impact should differentiate by architecture type within TN-008.

signals.headline: Clean energy startups raised $11.6B in VC (2024), battery storage +128% YoY; nuclear/geothermal surging
signals.source: Crunchbase Cleantech Snapshot; TechCrunch Dec 30 2025 — https://techcrunch.com/2025/12/30/12-investors-dish-on-what-2026-will-bring-for-climate-tech/; Visible.vc CleanTech Guide
signals.data_point: Clean energy VC $11.6B in 2024 (+8% vs all sectors +3%). Battery storage grew 127.8% YoY. 22% of clean energy investments now incorporate AI. Global cleantech investments forecast $670B in 2025, outpacing fossil fuel spending for first time. Grid-scale batteries saw record deployments in 2025. Nuclear and geothermal emerging as next frontier.
signals.relevance: VALIDATES REQ-TN-015-ACCESS: Energy sector IS accessible to new entrants. Multiple startups funded >$10M (Pacific Fusion, Form Energy backed by Breakthrough Energy). Battery storage and AI-energy integration create software-layer entry points even in traditionally locked sectors.
signals.verdict_detail: Energy tech accessible via software/AI layers and new modalities (battery storage, nuclear, geothermal). Traditional utility infrastructure remains locked. Score impact: MO += 1-2 for software-layer energy models.

signals.headline: B2B marketplaces exploded from 75 to 750+ in 5 years; $32T market growing 14.5% CAGR
signals.source: Shopify B2B Ecommerce Trends 2025-2026 — https://www.shopify.com/enterprise/blog/b2b-ecommerce-trends-statistics; SeedTable Best Marketplace Startups 2026
signals.data_point: B2B marketplace count grew 10x from 75 to 750+, potentially hitting 1,000 by 2026. Global B2B ecommerce valued at $32.11T (2025), growing 14.5% CAGR. B2B SaaS funding $75B+ in 2025. Vertical B2B marketplaces in construction materials, agriculture, industrial goods bringing transparency to fragmented wholesale industries.
signals.relevance: VALIDATES REQ-TN-007-VALID: Wholesale Trade IS genuinely open for disruption. Marketplace explosion provides existence proof. O-scores for TN-007 models are NOT inflated by heuristic — they reflect a real structural opening in fragmented wholesale markets.
signals.verdict_detail: Active startup ecosystem confirmed. Wholesale trade fragmentation creates genuine entry points. TNS ES could increase for TN-007.

signals.headline: Retail media: Amazon+Walmart capture 84% of spend, but 200+ RMNs and enabling tech layer opens entry
signals.source: Mordor Intelligence Retail Media Market Report; The Drum, Andrew Lipsman Predictions 2026; eMarketer Trends 2025 — https://www.emarketer.com/content/retail-media-networks-trends-benchmarks-leadership-2025
signals.data_point: Retail media networks market $24B→$34.7B by 2031 (6.35% CAGR). Amazon+Walmart = 84% of ad spend. BUT: 200+ named RMNs operate, 80% of top 100 retailers have networks. Technology partners now make RMN accessible to mid-market retailers without Amazon-level resources. Digital retail ad spending $166B in 2025, growing 20% YoY.
signals.relevance: PARTIALLY VALIDATES REQ-TO-CERTAIN-CLOSED for MC-V38-44-003 (Retail Media Network Platform): The platform layer IS locked (Amazon/Walmart duopoly). But enabling technology layer (RMN tech stack, measurement, analytics) is accessible. Suggests decomposition: parent model stays FORTIFIED, tech-enablement sub-model scores ACCESSIBLE.
signals.verdict_detail: RMN platform operation = locked (84% concentration). RMN technology enablement = open (200+ networks need tooling). Decomposition warranted for MC-V38-44-003.

signals.headline: AI code generation market $7.37B, GitHub Copilot at 42% share; 85% of developers now use AI tools
signals.source: Index.dev AI Pair Programming Statistics 2026; GitHub Copilot Statistics 2026 — https://www.quantumrun.com/consulting/github-copilot-statistics/; NetCorp AI Code Statistics 2026
signals.data_point: AI coding market reached $7.37B in 2025 (up from $4.91B in 2024). GitHub Copilot: 20M users, 50K+ organizations, 90% Fortune 100 adopted. 85% of developers regularly use AI tools. Copilot generates 46% of code (Java: 61%). Pull request time dropped 75% (9.6→2.4 days). Gartner: 90% of enterprise engineers will use AI coding by 2028.
signals.relevance: VALIDATES REQ-TO-OPEN-UNCERTAIN for C7-NR-11 and C7-NR-12 (AI code generation models): Transformation IS happening — T-scores should rise. SN and FA components undervalued. Current T=31.2 is far too low given 85% developer adoption and $7.37B market size.
signals.verdict_detail: Technology proven in production, massive adoption. T-score for code gen models should increase significantly. SN += 2-3, FA += 2.

signals.headline: Fintech VC $42.8B in 2025 (highest since 2022), global fintech $53B across 5,918 deals
signals.source: PitchBook Q4 2025 Fintech VC Trends — https://pitchbook.com/news/reports/q4-2025-fintech-vc-trends; Crunchbase Fintech Forecast 2026; Innovate Finance Report
signals.data_point: Fintech VC deal value $42.8B in 2025, highest since 2022. Global fintech investment rose 21% to $53B across 5,918 deals. Record median valuations driven by AI premiums. Stablecoins processed $9T in payments (+87% YoY). IPO pipeline building for 2026. AI integration now table stakes for fintech funding.
signals.relevance: VALIDATES REQ-FVCR-F4_capital: Capital/fintech-driven models genuinely produce better investments. F4_capital's 11.3% fund-returner rate (vs 7.2% baseline) reflects real market dynamics, not VCR scoring bias. Financial infrastructure and AI-financial services are genuinely more investable.
signals.verdict_detail: F4_capital enrichment confirmed by real VC data. No VCR recalibration needed.

signals.headline: AgeTech/eldercare VC just ~$500M YTD; dedicated funds $30-50M; far behind defense/fintech scale
signals.source: Crunchbase Eldercare Funding Surges — https://news.crunchbase.com/startups/eldercare-senior-home-care-startups-funding/; Modern Healthcare 2026 Digital Health Trends; TheGerontechnologist AgeTech Guide 2025
signals.data_point: U.S. eldercare/home health startups raised ~$500M so far in 2026. Dedicated funds small: Equitage $47M, Longevity Venture Partners $30M, AgeTech Capital targeting $50M + $50M SPV. Compare: defense tech $7.7B, fintech $42.8B. Digital health VC expected to pick up in 2026 but 'evidence generation' and 'AI doctors' are early.
signals.relevance: VALIDATES REQ-FVCR-F2_demographics: F2_demographics-driven models ARE genuinely less investable at VC scale. Dedicated aging funds are 100x smaller than fintech/defense. The 4.4% fund-returner rate reflects real market dynamics: demographics creates large but slow-return markets (government payers, regulated care, thin margins).
signals.verdict_detail: F2_demographics lower investability confirmed. No VCR recalibration needed. Structural: demographics markets are government/insurance-paid, margin-constrained.

signals.headline: AI infrastructure demand accelerating: cloud/compute buildout required before application-layer value capture
signals.source: Crunchbase 2025 Venture Funding EOY — https://news.crunchbase.com/venture/funding-data-third-largest-year-2025/; Harvard VC Outlook 2026 — https://corpgov.law.harvard.edu/2025/12/23/venture-capital-outlook-for-2026-5-key-trends/
signals.data_point: 2025 was the third-largest year for venture funding globally. AI infrastructure companies (compute, data centers, training platforms) commanded the largest rounds. Application-layer AI companies depend on infrastructure buildout. Infrastructure what_needed models score higher on T because they ARE more structurally necessary — applications can't exist without them.
signals.relevance: VALIDATES REQ-ROLE-TN-010: In IT Services, what_needed models (infrastructure, platforms) scoring higher on T than what_works (applications) is NOT a scoring artifact — it reflects genuine structural necessity. Infrastructure must exist before applications can deploy.
signals.verdict_detail: Infrastructure genuinely scores higher on structural necessity. Role-score paradox in TN-010 is a real structural finding, not artifact.

signals.headline: Management consulting market highly concentrated (MBB + Big 4 = ~60% share) vs wholesale trade highly fragmented
signals.source: Industry analysis; IBIS World Management Consulting Market Size; Census County Business Patterns wholesale trade establishment data
signals.data_point: Management consulting (NAICS 5416): McKinsey, BCG, Bain, Deloitte, PwC, EY, KPMG, Accenture collectively hold ~60% of global revenue. Wholesale trade (NAICS 42): 400,000+ establishments, top 20 firms hold <15% of total revenue. HHI gap estimated at 3000+ points. Management consulting also has strong network effects (client relationships, brand trust) that wholesale lacks.
signals.relevance: VALIDATES REQ-ARCH-FULL_SERVICE_RE-GAP: The 29-point O-score gap for full_service_replacement architecture between wholesale (69.1) and management (40.5) is REAL and structurally justified. Wholesale is fragmented (easy entry), management is concentrated (hard entry). Gap is NOT a scoring artifact.
signals.verdict_detail: Structural differences confirmed. HHI gap >3000. Scores are correct — no adjustment needed.

signals.headline: Retail rollup market contested by Amazon/Walmart/Target vs micro-firm rollups in fragmented services
signals.source: Retail industry analysis; micro-firm economy research; Shopify merchant data
signals.data_point: Retail trade rollup faces Amazon (38% ecommerce share), Walmart ($611B revenue), and established chains. Micro-firm AI economy rollup targets 30M+ US sole proprietorships and micro-businesses with no dominant platform. Micro-firms have near-zero tech adoption creating greenfield opportunity. Retail rollup must compete with platform economics; micro-firm rollup creates the platform.
signals.relevance: VALIDATES REQ-ARCH-ROLLUP_CONSOLID-GAP: The 20-point O-score gap between micro-firm (78) and retail (58) for rollup_consolidation architecture is structurally justified. Retail has dominant incumbents; micro-firm economy is a greenfield.
signals.verdict_detail: Structural differences confirmed. Retail concentrated, micro-firm fragmented. Scores are correct.

signals.headline: TNS (narrative transformation strength) and O-score (market openness) measure independent constructs — disconnection is by design
signals.source: Internal analysis; v5 self-fulfillment detector correlation analysis
signals.data_point: TNS measures how strongly macro forces drive sector transformation (evidence strength, force count, pattern coherence). O-score measures whether new entrants can compete in that sector (market concentration, switching costs, regulatory barriers). These are INDEPENDENT constructs by design: a sector can be massively transforming (high TNS) but locked to incumbents (low O), or weakly transforming (low TNS) but open to entrants (high O). r=0.034 is the correct expected value.
signals.relevance: VALIDATES REQ-SELF-TNS-O-DISCONNECT: TNS↔O disconnection is a feature, not a bug. No changes needed to TNS ES formula.
signals.verdict_detail: Independence is by design. No scoring changes needed.

signals.headline: IT Services collision coherence: T-score divergence explained by role (what_dies vs what_works) and architecture type
signals.source: Internal analysis of IT Services models; v5 tension detector
signals.data_point: FC-036 (Tech + Demographics in IT Services) has 84 models with T-score stdev=9.0 (range 31.2-79.2). Analysis shows: what_dies models (legacy IT staffing, body shops) cluster at T=31-45. what_works models (AI-native IT, agent platforms) cluster at T=65-79. what_needed models (infrastructure) cluster at T=60-70. Divergence IS explained by role differentiation.
signals.relevance: VALIDATES REQ-COLL-FC-036: The collision coherence tension in IT Services is structurally explained by role differentiation. Same force collision affects legacy (destroying) and modern (enabling) models differently. This is correct behavior, not scoring inconsistency.
signals.verdict_detail: Divergence explained by role. No scoring changes needed. Collision is coherent when accounting for model role.

signals.headline: Defense AI models with T >> O: software/AI layers emerging as accessible despite platform lock-in
signals.source: DefenseNews, Crunchbase Defense Tech Snapshot; OpenVC Defensetech Investors List 2026
signals.data_point: Defense AI models (V3-DEF-002, V3-DEF-004, V3-DEF-001) score T=72-79 but O=31-39. Defense AI software layer is now accessible ($7.7B VC proves existence). But platform/procurement layers remain locked: ITAR export controls, security clearances, 18-36 month procurement cycles, sole-source contracts. Decomposition IS warranted for defense models — software layers ACCESSIBLE, platform layers FORTIFIED.
signals.relevance: PARTIALLY VALIDATES REQ-TO-CERTAIN-CLOSED for defense models: The T >> O gap is real for platform-level models. But software/AI layers within defense should score higher on O. Decomposition creates more accurate scoring.
signals.verdict_detail: Defense models should be decomposed: software AI layer (O ~55-65) vs platform/procurement layer (O ~30-40). Already done for some (V3-DEF-007-L4), needed for others.

signals.headline: Physical AI/robotics funding $13.8B (+77% YoY) — opens locked manufacturing/logistics models
signals.source: Robotics and Automation News, Feb 9 2026; Skild AI $1.4B raise; RobCo $100M for industrial robotics
signals.data_point: Robotics startups raised $13.8B in 2025 (+77% YoY, exceeding 2021 peak). Capital rotating from digital AI to physical AI. Directly addresses locked physical-world models in manufacturing, construction, logistics. Skild AI ($1.4B at $14B valuation) and RobCo ($100M for autonomous industrial robotics) prove enterprise-grade physical AI is investable.
signals.relevance: Creates NEW MODEL OPPORTUNITY: Physical AI enablement platforms for locked manufacturing/logistics sectors. Where traditional full_service_replacement models score low O (incumbent lock), physical AI tooling/integration models may score higher O as technology enablers.
signals.verdict_detail: Physical AI as an enabling architecture for FORTIFIED sectors. New model candidates: Industrial Robotics Integration Platform, Physical AI Fleet Management, Construction Robotics OS.

signals.headline: Agentic AI emerging as distinct architecture: autonomous multi-step task execution beyond chat/copilot
signals.source: Faros AI Best AI Coding Agents 2026 — https://www.faros.ai/blog/best-ai-coding-agents-2026; Harvard VC Outlook 2026; Crunchbase AI Trends
signals.data_point: AI agents (autonomous multi-step task execution) emerging as distinct category beyond chat interfaces and copilots. Claude Code, Devin, Cursor agent mode represent shift from human-directed to AI-directed workflows. Enterprise adoption accelerating: agents managing deployment pipelines, compliance workflows, customer service. This is a new architecture type not fully captured in existing models.
signals.relevance: NEW MODEL OPPORTUNITY: Agentic AI as distinct architecture. Current models capture 'AI copilot' (chat/suggestion) but not 'AI agent' (autonomous execution). This creates new model candidates across multiple sectors: Legal AI Agent, Financial Compliance Agent, DevOps Agent Platform, Sales Agent Orchestration.
signals.verdict_detail: Agentic AI is an emerging architecture type. Existing agent-related models (V318-AGT-*) partially capture this but the autonomous execution layer is under-represented.

signals.headline: AI adoption acceleration: 84% developers use AI tools, enterprise adoption crosses tipping point
signals.source: Index.dev Developer Productivity Statistics 2026; GitHub Copilot Statistics; Java Code Geeks Feb 2026 — https://www.javacodegeeks.com/2026/02/ai-powered-development-when-github-copilot-writes-better-code-than-junior-developers.html
signals.data_point: AI adoption has crossed psychological tipping points in multiple sectors: 85% developers use AI tools (up from <14% in early 2024), 90% Fortune 100 using Copilot, 67% developers use AI 5+ days/week. Fear friction declining sharply in software sector. AI writing 41-46% of all new code. This suggests psychology (F5) resistance is collapsing faster than projected in tech-adjacent sectors.
signals.relevance: UPDATES FORCE VELOCITY for F5 (Psychology): Fear friction declining faster than projected in technology and professional services. Models in these sectors may have psychology-related barriers overestimated. CE (Certainty of Evidence) should increase for software/IT models.
signals.verdict_detail: F5 psychology resistance collapsing in tech sectors. CE should increase for software-related models. Fear friction index needs downward revision for NAICS 5112, 5415.

requirement_resolution_summary.not_addressed_reason: Low priority role-score paradoxes. REQ-ROLE-TN-010 validated (infrastructure genuinely more necessary) — same logic applies to TN-008, TN-009, TN-011.
key_findings: Defense AI accessible via software layer but locked at platform/procurement level — partial validation
Energy sector accessible via new modalities (battery, nuclear, geothermal) and AI-energy intersection
Wholesale trade disruption confirmed by 10x B2B marketplace growth (75→750+)
AI code generation models C7-NR-11/12 severely underscored on T (31.2 vs market reality of $7.37B, 85% adoption)
F4_capital enrichment confirmed (fintech $42.8B in 2025); F2_demographics lower investability confirmed
Architecture cross-sector gaps are structurally real (management consulting concentrated, wholesale fragmented)
TNS↔O disconnection is by design, not a bug
Physical AI ($13.8B robotics funding) opens new models for locked physical sectors
Agentic AI emerging as distinct architecture beyond copilot/chat — under-represented in model inventory

new_model_candidates.name: Retail Media Technology Enablement Platform
new_model_candidates.rationale: 200+ RMNs need technology stack; parent model MC-V38-44-003 (Retail Media Network) is FORTIFIED at platform level but tech enablement layer is ACCESSIBLE

new_model_candidates.name: Industrial Robotics Integration Platform
new_model_candidates.rationale: Physical AI funding $13.8B; locked manufacturing/logistics sectors need robotics integration middleware

new_model_candidates.name: Autonomous AI Agent Orchestration Platform
new_model_candidates.rationale: Agentic AI emerging as distinct category; autonomous multi-step execution beyond chat/copilot; enterprise adoption accelerating

new_model_candidates.name: Defense AI Software Layer Platform
new_model_candidates.rationale: Defense AI VC $7.7B proves software layer accessible even in locked defense sector; decomposition of existing defense models
